channel.title: Math Question
channel.description: Determine the value of k such that g(x)= 3x+k intersects the quadraic function f(x)= 2x^2-5x+3 at exactly one point.

item.title: Math Question
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“SETO, post:3, topic:327051”][quote author=chrisn2323 link=topic=423461.msg3109037#msg3109037 date=1264394586]
slope of g(x)= 3x+k = 3.

find dy/dx of f(x)= 2x^2-5x+3

set 3 = f’(x)

solve for x

use that value to find K.
[/quote]

Sorry i forgot to indicate that, with out using derivatives, basically using grade 11 mathematics. [/quote]
Shouldn’t you be in AP Calculus in 11th grade…?

Read full topic

item.title: Math Question
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

[quote=“SETO, post:3, topic:327051”][quote author=chrisn2323 link=topic=423461.msg3109037#msg3109037 date=1264394586]
slope of g(x)= 3x+k = 3.

find dy/dx of f(x)= 2x^2-5x+3

set 3 = f’(x)

solve for x

use that value to find K.
[/quote]

Sorry i forgot to indicate that, with out using derivatives, basically using grade 11 mathematics. [/quote]
what kind of bs is that? I learned calc in 11th grade.

Ok the other way to do it

2 functions: y = 2x^2 - 5x + 3
y = 3x + k
subtract them and you get 0 = 2x^2 -8x +3 -k

to get one root (ie only one solution to the system) you need to complete the square.
3-k needs to be equal to 2 in order to complete the square

3-k = 2
k = -5

Read full topic
